newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan lawmaker says Pretoria tie switch "good".
newsitem.headline: Taiwan lawmaker says Pretoria tie switch "good".

text.p: South Africa's decision to switch ties to Beijing from Taipei is "good" news, a Taiwanese opposition lawmaker said on Thursday.

"The government has used South Africa's recognition to beautify (Taiwan's isolation). Now we don't even have South Africa and I think that's good," said Shen Fu-hsiung, parliament whip of the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party.
Shen's party openly promotes Taiwan's independence from China, but has softened its stance in recent years.
"This can force the government to realise the truth of our isolation and work hard to create the environment for an independent, sovereign country," Shen told reporters.
South African President Nelson Mandela said on Wednesday that Pretoria would switch diplomatic ties to Beijing from Taipei by the end of 1997.

Beijing has regarded Taiwan as a renegade province not entitled to foreign ties since the Chinese civil war separated them in 1949. Both governments say they want reunification but under very different terms.
South Africa is the biggest of 30 countries, mostly underdeveloped states in central America and Africa, that recognise the Republic of China government in Taipei.
